i went over to my mom's house today to help her get things together for her move.  we were in the backyard painting furniture and talking when she said said something that made me think.  she said something to the effect of "you sure do have a heart for lost causes."  she went on to say that i am friends with people who she thinks i should give up on.  she said that i am willing to go out of my way to help my friends and do nice things for them, but how many of them would do the same for me.  she asked me if i realized that some of my friends have blaring negative personality traits.  i assured her that it wasn't that i didn't notice these people have negative qualities.  i know their downfalls, but i also see their positive qualities.  i'm able and willing to look past their negative traits and focus on the positive one.  i think the key word in the previous statement is "willing."  i choose to not focus on the bad qualities that are apparently quite obvious to my mom. i care about my friends because i concentrate on their positive qualities, not ignore the others. and maybe i am friends with a couple of people that some would consider lost causes, but i genuinely care about them and will continue to.  i'd hate for somebody to consider me a lost cause and give up on me.  everybody can't give up on the "lost causes."   i haven't... then again i don't consider them lost causes.

today is groundhog's day, and it also happens to be my father's birthday.  every year i call him because i can't bring myself to not call him. i was recently reading my friend's blog and she posted this.  i'm not sure where she got it, but i like it.

I've Learned

I've learned that you cannot make someone love you.
All you can do is be someone who can be loved.
The rest is up to them.
I've learned that no matter how much I care,
some people just don't care back.
And it's not the end of the world.
I've learned that it takes years to build up trust,
and only seconds to destroy it.
I've learned that it's not what you have in your life,
but who you have in your life that counts.
I've learned that you can get by on charm for about fifteen minutes.
After that, you'd better know something.

I've learned that you shouldn't compare yourself
to the best others can do,
but to the best you can do.
I've learned that it's not what happens to people,
It's what they do about it.
I've learned that no matter how thin you slice it,
there are always two sides.
I've learned that you should always leave loved ones with loving words.
It may be the last time you see them.
I've learned that you can keep going
long after you think you can't.

I've learned that heroes are the people who do what has to be done
When it needs to be done
regardless of the consequences.
I've learned that there are people who love you dearly,
but just don't know how to show it.
I've learned that sometimes when I'm angry I have the right to be angry,
but that doesn't give me the right to be cruel.
I've learned that true friendship continues to grow even over the longest distance.
Same goes for true love.
I've learned that just because someone doesn't love you the way you want them to
doesn't mean they don't love you with all they have.

I've learned that no matter how good a friend is,
they're going to hurt you every once in a while
and you must forgive them for that.
I've learned that it isn't always enough to be forgiven by others.
Sometimes you have to learn to forgive yourself.
I've learned that no matter how bad your heart is broken,
the world doesn't stop for your grief.
I've learned that our background and circumstances may have influenced who we are,
but we are responsible for who we become.
I've learned that just because two people argue, it doesn't mean that they don't love each other.
And just because they don't argue, it doesn't mean they do.

I've learned that sometimes you have to put the individual
ahead of their actions.
I've learned that two people can look at the exact same thing
and see something totally different.
I've learned that no matter the consequences,
those who are honest with themselves get farther in life.
I've learned that your life can be changed in a matter of hours
by people who don't even know you.
I've learned that even when you think you have no more to give,
when a friend cries out to you,
you will find the strength to help.

I've learned that writing,
as well as talking,
can ease emotional pains.
I've learned that the people you care most about in life
are taken from you too soon.
I've learned that it's hard to determine where to draw the line between being nice
and not hurting people's feelings and standing up for what you believe.
I've learned to love
and be loved.
I've learned...

1. getting my masters degree. - so i've wanted my masters degree for about the past three years.  there were a couple of reasons why i hadn't done anything to get it.  the first being i wasn't exactly sure what i wanted to get a masters in.  i knew that i didn't want to be in the classroom teaching 20some kids for the next 30 years, but i knew i still wanted to work with children and in the education field.  at first i thought a master to become a reading specialist was the way to go, but after thinking about it i decided that wasn't the way to go because i don't really like teaching reading.  after doing a bit of research, i decided on the field based masters program at ODU.  after i decided what masters to get the next obstacle loomed before me...the GRE.  now i'll be honest, the thought of taking that stupid test scared me. i heard it was a lot like the SAT and i didn't do so hot on the SAT so quite naturally there was some fear there, and plus it isn't a cheap test to take.  well one day i woke and decided that i was being dumb and needed to take the stupid test, so i registered to do so.  i did some of the practice questions online and did horribly.  so i put my computer down, prayed to God asking him for a miracle (because there was NO other way i was going to do well) and went to bed.  i woke up the next morning with peace, prayed one more time asking for a miracle, and went to take the test.  God definitely came through and provided a miracle.  i did better than i expected.  so i start my first masters class on june 23rd.  i'm excited about it although i know that will change as soon as i have work to do.  oh well, thus is life.  oh, and i almost forgot.  after i get my masters i plan to get an endorsement to be a gifted and talented teacher.  that's what i'll do when i get tired of having a classroom of students.  that way i'm still in the education field but i won't have as many students.  so that's my plan, we'll see how it goes.  
2.  my weight/health - since i've graduated i've put on some weight.  a first it crept up slowly and i was ok with it.  but over the past few months i've put on more and at a more rapid weight and i'm not ok with that.  by no means am i fat, but i'm not pleased with my the recent weight gain. a couple of weeks ago one of my co-workers told me that people like me make her sick because i'm skinny and i don't need to worry about losing weight.  i replied by telling her that's how some people get fat.  they gain 5 pounds and are ok with it, then it's 10 and they decide they can live with that, and then the next thing you know they've put on more weight than they want and at that point it's hard to get off. well i decided i was gonna get things under control before it's too late.  so i've been going to the gym 3 times a week and i'm seeing a difference and that makes me feel good.  in addition i actually found out that i don't hate exercising as much as i thought i did.  i don't absolutely love it, but it's not horrible.  plus, high blood pressure runs in my family so i'm trying to stay as healthy as possible in hopes that i can avoid it  or at least put it off for as long as possible.
3.  my finances - my mom has told me over and over that the time to get your money right is when your young and i'm listening and taking action.  about two weeks ago i paid my last car payment (early i might add)!  i'm happy about that.  so now i'm going to take that money to pay off my credit card, which i hope to have paid off by the end of the year.  after that the only debt i will have (besides the necessary ones like rent, insurance, electricity, water, etc.) will be my student loan.  and my goal with that is to pay that off as soon as possible.  not only will these things improve my credit, but they'll help me be a better steward of my money.  in addition, in the next few years i want to buy a house and it helps to have good credit.      
4.  me - that one is pretty self explanatory.   as i grow older i seem to become more of the person i want to be. i think the 20's are an age of self-discovery.  i've learned and continue to learn all sorts of things.  things i want out of life, things i just won't tolerate, the type of people i need to rid myself of, the tye of people who are a positive influence in my life, and generally what i want out of life and my goals and expectations are becoming more and more clear. improving as a person is a continuous process and i'm taking it one day at a time.

As most of you know, I'm a pretty happy go lucky and optimistic person.  As much as this is true, there are times when I slip into bouts of cynicism and pessimism.  I tend to look at everything negatively and don't have much faith in anyone or anything.  This morning I woke up and decided that I was tired of being cynical and negative.  That being so pessimistic was making things any easier or any better.  And I felt that by being pessimistic I was in a way doubting the things that God could do.  So I decided I was gonna claim victory in the situations I'm going through and walk by faith that God is going to work out things.  I know that God loves me and I have to have faith that he's gonna bring me out of these things and that he's gonna give me things greater than I could ever imagine.  I'm believing in that and I feel better already.  Things haven't started to get better yet, but I know they will.... I have faith that they will. 

Because I'm normally an optimistic person I tend to have faith in people.  I have faith that they'll do the things they say, or that they'll be a good friend to me.  Sometimes that's the case and sometimes it's not.  But because I want to think the best of people sometimes I tend to overlook and forgive things that perhaps I shouldn't.  I think in some cases people take advantage of my kindness and my wanting to believe the best about them.   I don't like to feel that I'm giving up on people, but sometimes I just have to back away from a person because it's best for me.  It's not that I care about them any less or that I have given up on them, it's just  what I need to do.  Sometimes that can be a hard thing for me because I tend to put other people before myself.  But when it seems that somebody is only looking out for themselves and has no regard for my feelings or isn't being a good friend to me (especially if I feel I've been a good friend to them) I have to step back and put myself first, because they aren't going to.  I have to admit, it's something I've been struggling with for a long time and unfortunately I've been taken advantage of.  Yeah, it sucks, but hey I'm not perfect and that's just one of my many flaws.  In the end, I feel good knowing I was the best friend I could be to that person...whether they appreciated it or not.

I should be doing lesson plans, but I cannot physically or mentally bring myself to do it.  I blame this all on last week.  Last week was the week from hell, and quite possibly the worst week i've had in my career thus far.  Yes, it was that bad.  And if i try to explain to you why it was so bad, you wouldn't see where I was coming from and you'd think I was being a baby.  But I'll try, but just be warned, you're more than likely not going to understand.  Ok, so on Monday...well Monday is just a hard day in itself becaue it's Monday for crying out loud.  But to add to that we had a PTA meeting and of course the first PTA meeting is always Open House.  That just means the parents come to our rooms and we explain to them what goes on and so on and so forth.  Sounds painless right? Well it's not, because you have to put on the "I'm so happy your child is in my class and I can't wait to work with you" face....that in itself is extremely painful because half of their kids are little shits who don't follow directions or are as dumb as a box of rocks.  Besides that you have parents that want to talk to you FOREVER, which equates to you and your teaching partner not leaving work until 8:40 pm.  Bleck!  And if that weren't bad enough, of course you have an early meeting Tuesday, Wednesday AND Thursday mornings.  And of course those meetings are a COMPLETE waste of your time....especially when those in charge are reading to you like you can't read.  I teach children all day, I think I've mastered the skill of reading!  Then on Wednesday afternoon (the morning of the earliest meeting) the obnoxious Reading Specialist brings you a memo telling you that your dumb as f*** principal is completely changing the way you teach Reading.  But remember ther principal has NO idea what goes on in your classroom and everything in the memo is complete and utter bulls***.  On top of that thye haven't given me half the materials I need to be an effective teacher, anyway!  And if that weren't bad enough, on Friday you're told by the secretary that on Monday you're receiving your 28th f***ing student! 28th!  Did I forget to mention that the other teachers only have 26, 26, and 24 students. But I'm getting my 28th?!?!  Did I also fail to mention that included in the 27 students that I already have are two autistic children?!  Now, I don't mind have the autistic children in my room AT ALL.  In fact now that their aid has them under control things are running smoothly, BUT I ALREADY HAVE 27 FREAKING KIDS!  Not to mention I literally have nowhere to put the 28th student...seriously.  So of course I'm angry, so I ask my principal about it.  Do you know what this stupid S.O.B. says to me? She says she didn't count the two autistic children because they come wit an aid? WTF?  But I'm still responsible for teaching them, grading their papers and making sure they pass the SOL BUT they don't count?! How on earth does that work.  But wait it gets better. So then she asks me if I'd rather have inclusion (which is special ed mixed with regular ed) and as I'm walking out of the office I tell her " At this point I don't know what I want" (which wasn't true, because I wanted to walk out of the building right then and there) and this b***h says to me "You'll deal."  You'll deal?!  What kind of unprofessional shit is that to say to me? I rolled my eyes and walked outta the office.   And I know that that may not sound like the makings of a crappy week to you, but it was.  It was jsut a bunch of little things that piled up on top of each other.  Normally something little will effect me, I let it bother me for a split second then I'll get over it, but last week I didn't have time to get over the first little thing before the next and the next and the next thing hit me.  Teachers who have been teaching for 20 years have said that the start to the school year has been the worst they have ever had.  So it makes me feel better.  It's waaay to early in the year to be feeling burnt-out already.  Is there anybody who wants to volunteer to help me grade papers?  I'd be willing to pay you in food.....dinner?  cookies?  We can bargain....I'm desperate.  Something has gotta give and if things don't get better soon, I'm afraid it's gonna be my sanity.

As I've stated several times before the summer was a time in which I did a lot of thinking and self-examining.  In doing so I've decided to work on some of my flaws.  I've also decided I'm gonna change some things.  For one, I'm gonna exercise regularly.  Within the last year or two my metabolism has slowed but my unhealthy eating habits haven't so it's catching up with me.  Sometime this week or this weekend I plan on joining a gym AND actually going.  I'll keep you updated on that.  Another thing I'm going to change is how I deal with work.  Yes, that's how I make a living and therefore it's important, but my job is not my life, it's simply a part of my life.  Meaning, it doesn't have to consume me and the majority of my time.  I plan on going in early or staying late to get my work done instead of bringing it home.  I think by doing that my work life won't mesh into my personal life.  I want the two of them to be separate entities.  Inevitably there are going to be times in which I'm going to have to bring work home, teaching has never been a leave it at the office type of career, but I'm going to make every effort to do only do so when it's absolutely necessary (i.e. progress report and report card time)  Another thing I want to improve on is being a neater person.  Those of you who know me well enough to have ever seen my room know that it's pretty much a permanent state of disarray. haha.  Sad, but true.  I have to admit, that since moving to the apartment I have kept it pretty clean (my line sisters whole-heartedly agree).  I'm definitely gonna try my best to keep it that way.   There are a couple of other things that I'm trying to improve on, but they're a bit more personal.  But here's to self-improvement....
